copy.headline: CVE-2025-46597 - Highly unlikely remote crash on 32-bit systems

microcopy.text: This issue is considered Low severity.
Disclosure of the details of a bug on 32-bit systems which may, in a rare edge case, cause the node to crash when receiving a pathological block. This bug would be extremely hard to exploit.
A fix was released on October 10th 2025 in Bitcoin Core v30.0.

copy.headline: About
copy.subheadline: About us

microcopy.text: Bitcoin Core is an open source project which maintains and releases Bitcoin client software called "Bitcoin Core".
It is a direct descendant of the original Bitcoin software client released by Satoshi Nakamoto after he published the famous Bitcoin whitepaper.
Bitcoin Core consists of both "full-node" software for fully validating the blockchain as well as a bitcoin wallet.
The Bitcoin Core project has a large open source developer community with many casual contributors to the codebase.

copy.headline: How to contribute code to Bitcoin Core

microcopy.text: The Bitcoin Core project operates an open contributor model where anyone is welcome to contribute towards development in the form of peer review, testing and patches.
Please refer to the contribution guide in the Git repository for more details.

copy.headline: Contact Us

microcopy.text: Bitcoin Core does not provide technical support.
microcopy.purpose: Sets clear expectations; 'not' in red for emphasis

microcopy.text: Community support can be found at bitcoin.stackexchange.com
You can report bugs in our software using the issue tracker.
You can find Bitcoin Core developers on IRC.
The following keys may be used to communicate sensitive information to developers:

dataFormatting: GPG fingerprints: 133E AC17 9436 F14A 5CF1 B794 860F EB80 4E66 9320
trustSignals: GPG key fingerprints for developers (Pieter Wuille, Michael Ford, Ava Chow)
